awd_titl_txt: Understanding and Predicting Properties and Performance of Additively Manufactured Nickel-Based Superalloys
awd_abstract_narration:
Additive manufacturing, or 3D Printing, offers tremendous opportunity for efficient, custom manufacturing of critical parts. This processing approach can be applied to Nickel-based superalloys, which are specialized materials that have excellent high-temperature strength and good oxidation resistance, and hence are used in a wide range of technologies and applications. This award supports research to understand the fundamental relationships between processing and performance which will allow development of optimal additive manufacturing processes to fabricate nickel-based superalloy parts.  An optimal process will enable the additively manufactured nickel-based superalloys to have excellent resistance to surface damage by high temperature oxidation while also retaining superior strength. Additively manufactured alloys have potential application in aerospace, automotive, biomedical, energy, and chemical industries. The results from this research therefore have the potential to benefit the U.S. economy and enhance manufacturing capabilities. Moreover, the research results will be incorporated into curriculum enhancement, student training, industrial collaboration, and an educational outreach program. Activities supported under this award will contribute to recruiting students from underrepresented groups to participate in research, and will positively impact higher education in science and engineering disciplines.

The combination of high strength and superior oxidation resistance of nickel-based superalloys make these materials good candidates for high-temperature applications. Additively manufactured nickel-based superalloys can possess mechanical properties comparable to those produced by conventional manufacturing techniques, but their resistance to high temperature oxidation is not comparable to conventionally manufactured components. To enable the application of additive manufacturing for high-temperature alloy fabrication, this research aims to understand and predict the processing-microstructure-oxidation relationships for additive manufactured nickel-based superalloys. The research team will fabricate nickel-based superalloys in layered forms using the laser engineered net shaping additive manufacturing technique,  perform microstructural analysis on the alloys using electron microscopy,  predict the solidification microstructure of the additive manufactured Ni alloys using numerical modeling techniques, and  measure the high-temperature oxidation performance of additive manufactured Ni alloys via thermogravimetric analysis.  This research will provide knowledge for determination of a critical cooling rate below which the superior high-temperature corrosion properties can be maintained in the additive manufactured nickel-based superalloys.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
Additive manufacturing is a revolutionizing technique for producing complex three-dimensional structures directly from a digital model and using material powders. The technique, also called 3D printing, has economic advantages of shortening the time from a design to final product and reducing materials waste. Nickel-based superalloys are specialized materials that have excellent high-temperature strength and good oxidation resistance, and hence are used in a wide range of technologies in aerospace, automotive, biomedical, energy, and chemical industries. This award supports research to acquire fundamental knowledge for the deployment of additive manufacturing to fabricate high-performance nickel-based superalloy parts.  Additively manufactured nickel-based superalloys possess mechanical properties comparable to those produced by conventional manufacturing techniques. However, their resistance to high temperature oxidation has been found to become deteriorated as compared to wrought ones. Consequently, the hypothesis of the project is that the formation of protective oxide scale on additively manufactured nickel-based superalloys is strongly influenced by the inhomogeneous distribution of some alloy constituents (such as, Mo and Nb) resulted from rapid solidification during additive manufacturing. To examine this hypothesis, the research team have fabricated nickel-based superalloys in layered forms using the various additive manufacturing techniques, performed microstructural analysis on the alloys using electron microscopies, predicted the solidification microstructure of the additively manufactured Ni alloys using numerical modeling techniques, and measured the high-temperature oxidation performance of additively manufactured Ni alloys via thermogravimetric analysis. The results from this research enable the additively manufactured nickel-based superalloys to have excellent resistance to surface damage by high temperature oxidation while also retaining superior mechanical strength, and hence benefit the U.S. economy and society.

Intellectual Merit: In this project, some advanced experimental and computational methods, which include Laser Engineered Net Shaping (LENS), direct energy deposition (DED), laser powder bed fusion (LPBF), scanning and transmission electron microscopies, and the first-principles density functional theory calculations, have been applied to measure and predict the extent of Nb and Mo segregation and high temperature oxidation property of additively manufactured Inconel 625 (IN625) alloy. Specifically, the notable results from this research are that (1) a similar degree of Mo and Nb segregation has been found in IN625 samples manufactured with three different additive manufacturing techniques including LENS, DED, and LPBF; (2) all the LENS, DED, and LPBF manufactured IN625 samples exhibit worse oxidation resistance than wrought IN625 sample at high temperature and in air, (3) an annealing heat-treatment following the additive manufacturing could reduce the degree of Mo and Nb segregation and enhance the high-temperature oxidation resistance property of the IN625 samples, (4) the segregation of Nb and Mo in the additively manufactured IN625 could cause the depletion of Cr in the same region, and (5) the fatigue performance of additively manufactured IN625 alloy is also affected negatively by the Nb and Mo segregation resulted from rapid solidification during additive manufacturing.

Broader Impacts: The outcomes of the research have an impact on a broad range of fields (such as aerospace, automotive, electronics, energy, biomedicine, implants and prosthetics, surgical devices, and dental orthodontics) which employ additive manufacturing to fabricate high-performance products. The computation tools developed in this project have been distributed in academic community to predict the segregation process in multicomponent alloys, the atomistic structure of high entropy alloy nanoparticles, and the structural evolution of bimetallic catalyst nanoparticles. Several research articles will appear in peer-reviewed scientific journals, and multiple technical presentations have been delivered at international conferences. The research results have been added as teaching materials of graduate and undergraduate courses. Through the entire life of the award, two PhD graduate students and four undergraduate students receive the research training in computational materials science and additive manufacturing. Moreover, the research results have been incorporated into curriculum enhancement, student training, industrial collaboration, and an educational outreach program. This award also helps underrepresented groups to participate in research and positively impacts higher education in science and engineering disciplines.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

 


Last Modified: 09/04/2021
Modified by: Guofeng Wang
